p: Among the asthma subjects, 45.0% had pathogens detected in this study. Most of the previous studies on detection of respiratory pathogens in asthma exacerbations were conducted in children [ 22]. A Korean study found that in adult asthma subjects with acute exacerbation, 26.3% had viruses identified in expectorated sputum, with HRV being the commonest virus detected [ 23]. A paediatric study in Hong Kong with children aged 3–18 years between January 2007 and February 2008 detected respiratory pathogens in 51.0% subjects, with HRV being the commonest organisms identified [ 24]. Adult subjects with asthma exacerbation thus appeared to have a lower rate of pathogens identified than in children.
